Advisors: Celia A. Schiffer, Nese Kurt Yilmaz, Patricia Z. Musacchio, George A. Kaminski
Title: Comparison of Sequences and Structures Between NS3-NS2B of Various Flaviviruses
Abstract: Flaviviridae is a family of single-stranded RNA viruses, which include Hepacivirus, Pestivirus, Pegivirus, and Flavivirus. Many members of the Flavivirus genus are known to cause fatal encephalitis and hemorrhagic illness in humans, such as Dengue virus (DENV), and Murray Valley virus (MVEV). By comparing sequences and structures between their Nonstructural protein 3 (a multi-purpose protein that is crucial for Flavivirus' RNA replication), using sequence alignment and structural alignment algorithm, this project's goal is to find conserved regions and sequences among those proteins. This information can help researchers examine the relatedness between the members of Flaviviruses, and develop effective treatment.

Students: Emily Stead, Kathryn Nippert, Luigi Apollon
Advisors: Jagan Srinivasan, Carissa Olsen, Angela C. Incollingo Rodriguez
Title: Selegiline: The Effects of Monoamine Oxidase Inhibitors on the Behavior and Physiology of Caenorhabditis Elegans
Abstract: This study observed the effects of Selegiline on behavioral and metabolic pathways of C. elegans by investigating egg laying behavior, locomotion, and lipid composition. Selegiline positively impacts egg-laying but negatively impacts locomotion. Lipid composition data revealed an increase in saturated FA content and decreased polyunsaturated FA content, suggesting FAT-2 or FAT-7 enzyme dysregulation. A survey of WPI students identified positive correlations between perceived stress and depressive symptoms with the average student's CES-D score measuring 24.2, which is considered depressed. These results highlight the increased prevalence and importance of understanding the physiology and biological mechanisms implicated in depression.

Students: Lily Cordner, Sammy Hankaoui, Delainey O'Connor, Emily Pollock, Blake Wofford
Title: A Preliminary Analysis of Healthcare Disparities Curriculum at WPI
Abstract: Undergraduate bioengineering and biomedical sciences curriculum is currently lacking the inclusion of healthcare disparities education. It is imperative to educate future healthcare professionals as early in their career as possible in order to mitigate these disparities in their later work. The purpose of this study was to look at the degree and manner in which students have intersected with healthcare disparities. Another focal point of the study was to examine the effectiveness of an educational module administered to students taking courses in biomedical sciences, bioengineering, and adjacent disciplines.
